creditline: Gift of funds from Lisa and Jud Dayton
description: Rare rolled paper decorated traveling writing box, fitted with a 'slave' medallion, Wedgwood, c.1787. The interior of the box is fitted for writing tools and retains its original salmon colored paper. England, c.1790; noteper Lotus Stack, Textile curator,'interior paper' is actually silk fabric.
inscription: \"AM I NOT A MAN AND A BROTHER?\" across the top of the medallion
medium: Rolled paper on wood with stoneware (jasper) medallion
object_name: Writing box with Wedgwood abolitionist medallion
text: The leading manufacturer of ceramics in Staffordshire, Josiah Wedgwood was also a founding member of the Society for the Abolition of the Slave Trade in England. In 1787 he directed his chief modeler, William Hackwood, to create a medallion depicting a kneeling African slave in chains. Adopted as the seal of the Society, the medallions were distributed free of charge to supporters of the abolitionist movement in Europe and America.
title: Writing box with Wedgwood abolitionist medallion
